texts.shortText: A tiny, cream-coloured, round-bodied dorid. Cryptically coloured to match the Rustic lace bryozoan (Membranipora rustica) on which it feeds. The head is cream-coloured with camouflage patterning. The rhinophores are cream-coloured. The notum is slightly humped, cream-coloured and patterned in a network of cream and brown. The gills are white with orange to yellow edging and blotches. The posterior end is rounded.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Western False Bay, 1â€“15m in depth.

Individuals of Corambe sp. are exclusively found on the Rustic lace bryozoan (Membranipora rustica), which itself can usually be found growing on fronds of the Sea bamboo (Ecklonia maxima). These species are exceptionally cryptic and the patterning of the nudibranch matches that of the bryozoan it lives and feeds on.
The species preys on the Rustic lace bryozoan, Membranipora rustica.
This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat white spiral.
This tiny species is distinctive when found, but is hard to spot because of its small size and cryptic coloration.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 208).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 95).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 416, 805).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 140).
